Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Bioinorganic Redox Chemistry and Protein-Protein Interactions at an Electrode

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. Microbes such as Nitrosomonas europaea and Shewanella oneidensis are capable of remarkable biochemical transformations as part of their overall metabolism. Like all living things, micro-organisms harness energy by elaborate schemes in which electrons move from one protein molecule to another, forming a kind of internal circuitry. Traditionally, the determination of the composition and circuitry of the inner electrical workings of a cell would be quite difficult. In this research, a new analytical tool, protein film voltammetry, will be used to learn about the fundamental ways N. europaea and S. oneidensis move electrons within the components of their internal circuitry. Specifically, this project will report upon the oxidation/reduction (redox) properties of monoheme and multiheme cytochromes as individual purified proteins and macromolecular complexes. A series of multiheme electron transfer proteins (CymA, MtrA, STC, cyt c554, and cyt cm552) will be studied to understand the potential role redox-cooperativity plays in the function of these proteins. Then, model protein-protein complexes will be prepared and analyzed electrochemically, to determine how protein-protein interactions influence and modulate the thermodynamics and kinetics of biological electron transfer. Ultimately, this project will focus on determination of how protein electrochemistry can be used as a rapid tool for the identification of labile, redox-active protein-protein complexes.

Broader impacts. This project will provide important insights into functional, labile protein-protein interactions as well as aid the development of protein electrochemistry as an analytical tool. Understanding the complex electrochemical pathways of N. europaea and S. oneidensis will enable the exploitation of these organisms in the bioenergy sciences. Further, the multi-disciplinary research will proceed alongside an educational plan that will develop (1) a new, first-year chemistry course that provides an interdisciplinary, problem- and research-oriented learning environment; (2) multi-disciplinary graduate courses in bioinorganic chemistry; (3) a seminar series in graduate research conduct and ethics, and (4) a conduit for undergraduate and high-school summer research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micro-organisms in the world around us make use of a diverse chemical processes for capturing and transmuting energy. Ultimately, such processes require the action of enzymes and proteins that are capable of passing electrical charge, making them the “wiring” that allows for the microbe to live. In this project, the Elliott group has made great progress in understanding how different kinds of proteins and enzymes pass charge at the level of molecules, through studying both very complicated proteins that can shuttle not one electron, but many, as well devising new methods for determining the organization or pathways by which different proteins can interact together to move charge over long distances.  Such efforts have resulted in new perspectives of how Nature makes use of the element Iron as an essential component found as the heart of the charge-carrying capacity of biological structures called hemes.  This project has focused on studying simple enzymes that have one heme (and therefore can carry or shuttle one-electron) as well as complex enzymes, where the proteins involved have as many as ten heme cofactors -- a very unusual circumstance. Amazingly, such apparently exotic proteins are founds in ubiquitous micro-organisms in the natural world around us. By studying how such organisms are capable of putting together simple and more complicated heme-bearing proteins, the Elliott group has shown that Nature does have fundamental principles for directionality and cooperativity in electron transfer chemistry. These ideas can be used in the future in the harnessing of micro-organisms to develop biofuels and to engineer solutions to current challenges in the energy sciences.

Through the course of our project, we have have several key outcomes. First, we have used analytical tools that monitor the electron-transfer chemistry of the heme units, to show that hemes can be used to move electrons either one at a time, or two at a time, but that the latter case is an apparently rare exception to the general rule of how nature uses heme in proteins. We have also found that there are key structural features that control the ability of a heme iron to pick up, or release an electron, and that these traits can be predicted on the basis of the sequence of amino acids found in the protein structure. We have used our expertise in developing analytical experiments to show how proteins that are part of a energetic network (the “wiring” alluded to above) work together in a specific way: that electrons flow from one protein to the next with a surprising degree of specificity and unidirectionality. Finally, we have measured the length of one of these ten-heme containing proteins, to understand just how long of a wire it may be.  Together, these findings are useful for informing how biological structures or microorganisms can be used in the development of biofuels.

Additionally, this project helped supported the educational activities of the Elliott group. Through the re-invention of a freshman chemistry curriculum for Boston University students, over 500 undergraduates were trained in not only the fundamentals of chemistry, a requirement for science literacy, but in cutting edge problems in the biochemical and energy sciences; the end result has been getting students involved in their own scientific research faster, and facilitating the retention of freshman as science students. In the Elliott group itself, over the time of the project, more than 10 undergraduates have been involved in research activities, many of them going on to graduate school in the sciences or other professional schools.
